sen.j: 国学（こくがく）は、日本の江戸時代中期に勃興した学問である。
sen.e: Kokugaku was the study that rose at the mid-Edo Period in Japan.
Kokugaku was a study that took place in the mid-Edo Period in Japan.

sen.j: 蘭学と並び江戸時代を代表する学問の1つである。
sen.e: It was one of the studies that represented the Edo Period along with Ran Gaku (Dutch learning).

sen.j: 和学・皇朝学・古学（古道学）などの別名がある。
sen.e: It had other names of Wagaku (Japanese study), Kochogaku, Kogaku (Kodogaku).
It was also called Wagaku (Japanese study), Kochogaku, Kogaku (Kodogaku).

sen.j: それまでの「四書五経」をはじめとする儒教の古典や仏典の研究を中心とする学問傾向を批判し、日本独自の文化・思想、精神世界を日本の古典や古代史のなかに見出していこうとする学問である。
sen.e: It criticized the former study inclined toward studying classics of Confucianism such as "Four Books and Five Classics" and Buddhist classics, and it was a study that tried to discover culture, thoughts, spiritual world unique to Japan within Japanese classics and classical history.

It criticized former studies inclined toward the classics of Confucianism such as "Four Books and Five Classics" and Buddhist classics, and it was a study that tried to discover culture, philosophy, the spiritual world unique to Japan within the Japanese classics and classical history.

Kokugaku criticized the heretofore strong academic focus on Confucian and Buddhist classics, especially the "Four Books and Five Classics" of Confucianism, trying instead to unearth native Japanese cultural, philosophical, and spiritual traditions to be found in the Japanese classics and ancient histories.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 国学の方法論は、国学者が批判の対象とした伊藤仁斎の古義学や荻生徂徠の古文辞学の方法から大きな影響を受けている。
sen.e: The methodology of Kokugaku was influenced by Kogigaku (modern school of Confucianism in Japan) of Jinzai ITO or of Kobunjigaku (Study of Ancient Rhetoric) by Sorai OGYU that Kokugaku scholars criticized.

The methodology of Kokugaku was influenced by Kogigaku (modern school of Confucianism in Japan) of Jinzai ITO or of Kobunjigaku (Study of Ancient Rhetoric) by Sorai OGYU that Kokugaku scholars criticized.

Yet the methodology of Kokugaku was heavily influenced by Jinzai ITO's Kogigaku (a Confucian school) and by Sorai OGYU's Kobunjigaku (study of ancient rhetoric) even though Kokugaku scholars criticized these schools.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 儒教道徳、仏教道徳などが人間らしい感情を押し殺すことを否定し、人間のありのままの感情の自然な表現を評価する。
sen.e: The morals of Confucianism and Buddhism suppressed and killed emotions of a human and valued natural human expression.
The morals of Confucianism and Buddhism suppressed and killed human emotions and valued natural human expression.
Kokugaku rejected the moral philosophy of both Confucianism and Buddhism, which forced people to repress natural human emotions, instead placing value on the natural expression of human emotions.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 江戸時代に形骸化した中世歌学を批判するかたちで現れた。
sen.e: It appeared as a form to criticize medieval Kagaku (Study of Japanese poems called waka) that fell to ruins during the Edo Period.
It appeared as a form to criticize medieval Kagaku (Study of Japanese poems called waka) that lost it's popularity during the Edo Period.

sen.j: 木下勝俊・戸田茂睡らに始まるこうした批判は、下河辺長流・契沖の『万葉集』研究に引き継がれた。
sen.e: The criticisms that started with Katsutoshi KINOSHITA and Mosui TODA continued by the research of "Manyoshu" (The Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves) by Choryu (also called as Nagaru) SHIMOKOBE and Keichu.

The criticisms that started with Katsutoshi KINOSHITA and Mosui TODA continued under the research of "Manyoshu" (The Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves) by Choryu (also called as Nagaru) SHIMOKOBE and Keichu.

The criticisms that started with Katsutoshi KINOSHITA and Mosui TODA continued in the research of "Manyoshu" (The Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves) conducted by Choryu (also pronounced "Nagaru") and Keichu SHIMOKOBE.

sen.j: 特に後者の実証主義的な姿勢は古典研究を高い学問水準に高めた事で高く評価されている。
sen.e: The inclination of later party practicing positivism was greatly praised for making the Classics research having the strong academic standard.
The inclination of the later party practicing positivism was greatly praised for undertaking research on the Classics upholding strong academic standards.
In particular, the tendency towards positivism seen in Keichu's work was greatly praised for raising the academic standards of research into the Classics.

sen.j: 続いて伏見稲荷の神官であった荷田春満が神道や古典から古き日本の姿を追求しようとする「古道論」を唱えた。
sen.e: In addition, Azumamaro KADANO, who was the Shinto priest at Fushimi Inari Shrine, expressed "Kokudoron" (Argument of Old Path) that tried to pursue the ancient appearance of Japan from Shinto or the Japanese Classics.

In addition, Azumamaro KADANO, who was a Shinto priest at Fushimi Inari Shrine, expressed "Kokudoron" (Argument of Old Path) that tried to pursue the ancient appearance of Japan from Shinto or the Japanese Classics.

In addition, Azumamaro KADANO, a Shinto priest of Fushimi Inari Shrine, contributed his "Kodoron" (Theory on the Ancient Ways), in which he tried to recapture the essence of ancient Japan by studying Shinto and the Japanese Classics.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 一部において矛盾すら含んだ契沖と荷田春満の国学を体系化して学問として完成させたのが賀茂真淵である。
sen.e: KAMO no Mabuchi formalized Kokugaku as academia by incorporating even some contradictions made by Keichu and Kokugaku of Azumamaro KADANO.

sen.j: 真淵は儒教的な考えを否定して『万葉集』に古い時代の日本人の精神が含まれていると考えてその研究に生涯を捧げた。
sen.e: Mabuchi denied the thoughts of Confucianism and believed that "Manyoshu" contained Japanese spirits of old times, and devoted his life on such research.
Mabuchi denied the thoughts of Confucianism and believed that the "Manyoshu" contained the Japanese spirit of olden times, and devoted his life on such research.
Mabuchi rejected Confucian thought and believed that the true spirit of the ancient Japanese was to be found in the "Manyoshu", devoting his life to researching it.

sen.j: 真淵の門人である本居宣長は『古事記』を研究して、古い時代の日本人は神と繋がっていたと主張して「もののあはれ」の文学論を唱える一方で『古事記伝』を完成させた。
sen.e: Norinaga Motoori, who was the disciple of Mabuchi, researched "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), stressed that Japanese of ancient times were connected to gods and lectured "Mononoaware" (what was believed to be the core or idea of literature during the Heian Period) literary argument while completing the "Kojikiden."

sen.e: Norinaga Motoori, a disciple of Mabuchi, researched the "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), and stressed that ancient Japanese were connected to gods and lectured the "Mononoaware" (what was believed to be the core or idea of literature during the Heian Period) literary argument while completing the "Kojikiden."

Norinaga MOTOORI, one of Mabuchi's disciples, researched the "Kojiki" (Record of Ancient Matters), stressing that the ancient Japanese had been closely connected to the gods, and also completed the "Kojikiden" (Commentary on the Kojiki), in which he advanced the literary theory of "mono no aware" (the pathos of things).
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: その後宣長門人の平田篤胤に至って宣長の持つ「古道論」を新たな神道である「復古神道」に発展させた。
sen.e: Atsutane HIRATA, who was the disciple of Motoori, later developed "Kodoron" of Motoori into the "Fukko shindo" (Restored Way of Gods) of Shintoism.
Atsutane HIRATA, a disciple of Motoori, later developed "Kodoron" of Motoori into the "Fukko shindo" (Restored Way of Gods) of Shintoism.
Atsutane HIRATA, a disciple of Norinaga's, later developed the ideas expressed in Norinaga's "Kodoron" into the "Fukko shinto" (Restored Shinto), a new form of Shinto.

sen.j: 彼の思想は江戸時代後期の尊皇攘夷思想にも影響し、日本固有の文化を求めるため、日本の優越性を主張する国粋主義や皇国史観にも影響を与えた。
sen.e: His ideology influenced Sonno joi (Revere the Emperor, Expel the Barbarians) at the end of Edo Period, and sought unique Japanese culture as well as affecting the Kokujun Ideology (ideology trying to keep Japanese art pure) and Kokokukan (ideology that Japanese history is centered around generations of emperors) stressing on the prestigiousness of Japan.

His ideology influenced Sonno joi (Revere the Emperor, Expel the Barbarians) at the end of the Edo Period, and sought a unique Japanese culture as well as affecting the Kokujun Ideology (ideology trying to keep Japanese art pure) and Kokokukan (ideology that Japanese history is centered around generations of emperors) stressing the prestigiousness of Japan.

Atsutane's ideas influenced both the development of the Sonno joi (revere the Emperor, expel the barbarians) ideology at the end of the Edo period as well as the principle of Kokujun (keeping Japan's culture pure) and Kokokukan (the theory that Japanese history is centered around Japan's Emperors), both of which stressed the preeminence of Japan.

sen.j: 平田篤胤の弟子である経世家の佐藤信淵の著作『垂統秘録』や『混同秘策』等にはその傾向がよく現れている。
sen.e: Such inclinations were frequently expressed in written works such as the "Suitohiroku" and "Kondo Hisaku" (concerning about Japan conquering the world) by Nobuhiro SATO, who was the pupil of Atsutane HIRATA and the practitioner of Keisei School (one form of social and political ideology).

Atsutane's ideas also frequently found expression in works such as "Suito hiroku" and "Kondo hisaku" by his disciple, the intellectual Nobuhiro SATO.

sen.j: だが、真淵の門人であった村田春海らのように契沖以来の実証主義的な古典研究を重視する立場から平田国学に否定的な学派もあり、その内情は複雑であった。
sen.e: However, people such as Harumi MURATA, who was the disciple of Mabuchi, were in the academic school which criticized Kokugaku of Hirata from their stance of valuing Classic Study which focused on positivism since Keichu, and its internal condition was complex.

However, people such as Harumi MURATA, a disciple of Mabuchi, were of the academic school which criticized the Kokugaku of Hirata from their stance of valuing Classic Study which focused on positivism since Keichu, that was complex internally.

However, some--including Harumi MURATA, a disciple of Mabuchi--belonged to schools of thought that criticized Atsutane's Kokugaku from the standpoint of, since the time of Keichu, espousing positivism and placing great value on the study of classic works, arguing that internally it was more complex than that.

sen.j: 実証主義的な国学は明治の小中村清矩らの手によって近代以降の日本文学研究や国語学、民俗学の基礎となった。
sen.e: The Kokugaku, which stressed on positivism became the base of modern Japanese Literature study, National Language Study, and Ethnology by the work of Kiyonori KONAKAMURA.
